Minha opinião: É um filme onde um empresário quer lucrar com as apostas on line no mundo todo. Então ele decide fazer uma competição com condenados a morte que estão pelos presídios do mundo e trazer para sua ilha e fazer eles se confrotarem uns com os outros e quem vencer terá sua liberdade. Enquanto todos os participantes são assassinos, traficantes, guerrilheiro,.... Tem um bom rapaz que entro por ultimo, substituindo um participante. E quem é? Steve Austin, um ex-fuzileiro e bom moço que estava preso injustamente. E assim começa a competição. Acontecem atrocidades, estupro, traição,....... E vai assim morrendo um atrás do outro. Até que no fim Austin se liberta e vai atrás do grande vilão. Existem várias versões deste estilo de filme, e este não é dos melhores. Mediano para fraco. E existe cenas fortes de crueldade, que não seria necessário.

Honestly, this is one of my all-time favorite action flicks.  Particularly for a low-budget film.  Acting throughout is solid, albeit a little lackluster at times, but I think they really nailed the premise here which is what I liked most about The Condemned.  This isn't a mindless action film, it's got depth to it and almost acts as a fictional social experiment; making an unrealistic storyline come to life by highlighting just how terrible humanity can be. It perfectly depicts the depravity of society tuning in, in droves to pay to witness live murder, torture and rape.  The emotional rollercoaster is also captured brilliantly.  First, it seems like you've tuned in to watch a real-life Battle Royale, but as it gets darker, you see the characters (namely Hoffman and Musset) start to question their own involvement and morality.  Hoffman's performance was a stand out for me in that regard.  I strongly believe this is almost exactly how this would play out in a real life scenario.  The excuse of: "Well, they're going to die anyway and they're murderers, so who cares what they go through" is precisely how society would react in my opinion and Wiper captures that beautifully.  Robert Hammone encapsulates greed and selfishness to a tee and it worked as stark reminder that people are willing to sell anything, with no regard for human life, if it lines their pockets.  Most of the action scenes are tons of fun to watch, even though some of the dialogue is a little cringe at times.  Austin plays his role perfectly and bounced off Jones - who is as sadistic as they come - exceptionally well.  While the storyline is predictable, I was okay with the "happy ending" in this one and I highly recommend giving it a watch if you're into OTT action movies.

(B-)

'The Condemned' simply isn't a great film, due to its subpar acting, mostly predictable plot and average other aspects like the cinematography. However, I can't deny it still makes for solid action viewing. Just to be enjoyed for what it is.

With that said, it actually does have an interesting concept - one that is kinda fascinating. The film commits to it fairly well, hitting many correct notes in regards to the morality of the matters at hand. I also didn't think it would take such a dark-ish tone with it all.

Steve Austin is decent in the main role, he is no Dwayne Johnson or even John Cena but he has the right look for a beefed up protagonist. Vinnie Jones is Vinnie Jones in this, he's exactly how you'd expect him to be. The rest of the cast are largely forgettable, though Madeleine West actually gives the film's best performance as Sarah - despite only appearing in a minor part, I felt her character's feelings. It's also cool to see Rick Hoffman in a role pre-'Suits'.

If you just want pure action with loads of fighting, this is one for you. The second act and the last remnants of the ending drag, but it's largely a fun watch if you don't take it too seriously.

Overall, alright film.
